items.title: release upload error occurred on travis
items.body:
by #55, we have upload script by using jazzband bot that invoked from travis.
However we can't upload release files by error.

Travis log: https://travis-ci.org/jazzband/django-redshift-backend/jobs/485747325#L390

> HTTPError: 400 Client Error: File already exists. for url: https://jazzband.co/projects/django-redshift-backend/upload

refs:
* https://github.com/jazzband/django-redshift-backend/issues/51#issuecomment-458469824

@jezdez Can you check this issue?

items.title: UUIDField support: How does it work?
items.body:
Subject: When using `UUIDField`: `django.db.utils.ProgrammingError: type "uuid" does not exist`

### Problem
- Redshift doesn't support `uuid` data type but `django-redshift-backend`'s documentation states that [`UUIDField` is supported by using another type mapping](https://django-redshift-backend.readthedocs.io/en/master/refs.html#differences-from-postgres-psycopg2-backend)
- It turns out I don't figure out how to make it work.

#### Procedure to reproduce the problem

- Create a model which uses `django.db.models.UUIDField`
```python
class SomeModel:
    uuid = models.UUIDField(default=uuid.uuid4, editable=False)
    # some other fields
```
- Try to save an instance of the model.
```python
>>> some_instance = SomeModel()
>>> some_instance.save(using='some_database')
```
- My database uses `django-redshift-backend`:
```python
>>> django.db.connections['some_database']
<django_redshift_backend.base.DatabaseWrapper object at 0x7f17ee6f35c0>
>>> django.db.connections['some_database'].data_types['UUIDField']
'varchar(32)'
```

#### Error logs / results
- Traceback:
```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/models/base.py", line 718, in save
    force_update=force_update, update_fields=update_fields)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/models/base.py", line 748, in save_base
    updated = self._save_table(raw, cls, force_insert, force_update, using, update_fields)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/models/base.py", line 831, in _save_table
    result = self._do_insert(cls._base_manager, using, fields, update_pk, raw)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/models/base.py", line 869, in _do_insert
    using=using, raw=raw)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/models/manager.py", line 82, in manager_method
    return getattr(self.get_queryset(), name)(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/models/query.py", line 1136, in _insert
    return query.get_compiler(using=using).execute_sql(return_id)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/models/sql/compiler.py", line 1289, in execute_sql
    cursor.execute(sql, params)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/backends/utils.py", line 100, in execute
    return super().execute(sql, params)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/backends/utils.py", line 68, in execute
    return self._execute_with_wrappers(sql, params, many=False, executor=self._execute)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/backends/utils.py", line 77, in _execute_with_wrappers
    return executor(sql, params, many, context)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/backends/utils.py", line 85, in _execute
    return self.cursor.execute(sql, params)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/utils.py", line 89, in __exit__
    raise dj_exc_value.with_traceback(traceback) from exc_value
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/backends/utils.py", line 85, in _execute
    return self.cursor.execute(sql, params)
django.db.utils.ProgrammingError: type "uuid" does not exist
```
- Raw SQL query: 
```sql
(0.167) INSERT INTO "someapp_somemodel" ("field1", "field2", "field3", "field4", "field5", "field6", "field7", "field8", "field9", "uuid", "field11", "field12", "field13", "field14") VALUES ('', NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, 'unk', '7a6b990a-c24b-4146-adb7-986b3fe7724d'::uuid, '', 'json', NULL, 2);
```
- Corresponding Python arguments:
```python
args=['', None, None, None, None, None, None, None, 'unk', UUID('7a6b990a-c24b-4146-adb7-986b3fe7724d'), '', 'json', None, 2]
```

#### Expected results
I would expect that the uuid data type is not used when saving the instance in the database. Then again, maybe I'm doing things wrong and I completely miss something important when trying to use `UUIDField`. In this case, maybe the documentation should be updated to teach users how to use it?

### Environment info
- OS: Docker container built by using the `python:3.6` image
- Python version: `3.6.6`
- Django version: `2.1.3` (I know `django-redshift-backend` is not supposed to support Django2.1 yet, but then why is such an issue happening anyway?)
- Django-Redshift-Backend version: `0.9.1`

items.title: AttributeError: 'AutoField' object has no attribute 'rel'
items.body:
Subject: Encounter issue when migrate

### Problem
- Dear team,
This package helps a lot, thanks for develop such a tool.
But I followed the doc, while I want to migrate, below issue happens:

```
Operations to perform:
  Apply all migrations: admin, auth, contenttypes, redshift, sessions
Running migrations:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "manage.py", line 15, in <module>
    execute_from_command_line(sys.argv)
  File "/venv/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 371, in execute_from_command_line
    utility.execute()
  File "/venv/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 365, in execute
    self.fetch_command(subcommand).run_from_argv(self.argv)
  File "/venv/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/base.py", line 288, in run_from_argv
    self.execute(*args, **cmd_options)
  File "/venv/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/base.py", line 335, in execute
    output = self.handle(*args, **options)
  File "/venv/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/commands/migrate.py", line 200, in handle
    fake_initial=fake_initial,
  File "/venv/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/db/migrations/executor.py", line 91, in migrate
    self.recorder.ensure_schema()
  File "/venv/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/db/migrations/recorder.py", line 55, in ensure_schema
    editor.create_model(self.Migration)
  File "/venv/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django_redshift_backend/base.py", line 168, in create_model
    if field.rel and field.db_constraint:
AttributeError: 'AutoField' object has no attribute 'rel'
```

### Environment info
- OS: Linux version 4.14.62-65.117.amzn1.x86_64 (mockbuild@gobi-build-60009) (gcc version 7.2.1 20170915 (Red Hat 7.2.1-2)
- Python version: Python 3.4.3
- Django version: Tried Django 1.11, 2.05 and 2.08, all the same

Here is my setting:
```
DATABASES = {
    # 'default': {
    #     'ENGINE': 'django.db.backends.sqlite3',
    #     'NAME': os.path.join(BASE_DIR, 'db.sqlite3'),
    # },
    'default': {
        'ENGINE': 'django_redshift_backend',
        'NAME': 'name',
        'USER': 'root',
        'PASSWORD': 'psw',
        'HOST': 'host',
        'PORT': '5439',
    }
}
```

Model file:
```
from django.db import models

# Create your models here.

class test_redshift_django(models.Model):
    _database = 'redshift_db'
    name = models.CharField(max_length=10)
```

Migration file:
```
from django.db import migrations, models


class Migration(migrations.Migration):

    initial = True

    dependencies = [
    ]

    operations = [
        migrations.CreateModel(
            name='test_redshift_django',
            fields=[
                ('id', models.AutoField(auto_created=True, primary_key=True, verbose_name='ID')),
                ('name', models.CharField(max_length=10)),
            ],
        ),
    ]
```

Could you please help take a look what might goes wrong?

items.title: 0.9.1 release

items.body:
I'm going to make a release 0.9.1 for minor update before project transferring to Jazzband(#30).

Changes

* Fix wrong LICENSE indication on trove classifier https://github.com/shimizukawa/django-redshift-backend/commit/e8d12375d6d2ae7c493ded43dd8625d62c5ba809
* Minor update documentation
* #33 Create our Code of Conduct

I will release them within one or two weeks.
Please comment if there are opinions or objections.

See also: https://jazzband.co/about/guidelines#conduct

items.title: Create .github/CONTRIBUTING.md
items.body:
For #30 solving, we must have CONTRIBUTING.md with jazzband specified header (see: https://jazzband.co/about/guidelines#contributing-guidelines)

header:
```
[![Jazzband](https://jazzband.co/static/img/jazzband.svg)](https://jazzband.co/)

This is a [Jazzband](https://jazzband.co/) project. By contributing you agree to abide by the [Contributor Code of Conduct](https://jazzband.co/about/conduct) and follow the [guidelines](https://jazzband.co/about/guidelines).
```

items.title: Documentation

milestone.title: release-0.9
milestone.description:
Changes

* #35 Drop EOL versions.
* #40 Support Django 2.0.
* #42 Add support DistKey.

And #31 Documentation if I can make a time.

items.body:
For #30 solving, we need to prepare documentation for end users and contributors.
Inline code comments are also recommended.

I think there are the following steps:

Infrastructure:

- [x] create sphinx project on `/doc/` directory.
- [x] prepare ReadTheDocs for `/doc/` -> http://django-redshift-backend.rtfd.io/
- [x] link from PyPI project page to ReadTheDocs page

contents:

- [x] pages for end users
- [ ] pages for contributors
- NOT NEEDED: API references.

items.title: consider transferring ownership of this repository to Jazzband community

milestone.title: release-1.0
milestone.description:
- The first release from Jazzband organization.
- Using semver https://semver.org/ from version 1.0.
- Using `Development Status :: 5 - Production/Stable`.

items.body:
I consider transferring ownership because:

- I am using Redshift less frequently
- Because my life has changed, I have not enough spare time anymore.

The candidate for ownership transfer destination is https://jazzband.co/

-----

According to the [Jazzband guideline](https://jazzband.co/about/guidelines), before transferring a project to the jazzband organization, the following is required.

1. Viability: the project must not a snippet or not a one-off toys.
2. Documentation: for end users and contributors. Inline code comments are also recommended.
3. Tests: Auto testing on CI.
4. Conduct: Projects are required to adopt and follow the Jazzband code of conduct. 
5. Contributing Guidelines: CONTRIBUTING.md with jazzband specified header.
6. Badges: jazzband organization badge (optional)

In order to satisfy these conditions before transfer, I would like to invite cooperative developers of this project.

items.title: annotate() does not work on Django-1.9 and later

milestone.title: release-0.8
milestone.description:
Release (NEW) version 0.8 with current contents before making major changes.

The milestone which had previously been called 0.8 has been renamed to 0.9.
https://github.com/shimizukawa/django-redshift-backend/milestone/1

items.body:
Following query does not work on Django-1.9 and later:
```python
TestParentModel.objects.annotate(cnt=Count('testchildmodel')).query
```
```python
# models.py
class TestParentModel(models.Model):
    age = models.IntegerField()


class TestChildModel(models.Model):
    parent = models.ForeignKey(TestParentModel)
    age = models.IntegerField()
```

An above query causes `ProgrammingError` exception:
```
column "testapp_testparentmodel"."age" must appear in the GROUP BY clause or be used in an aggregate function
```

When the exception is raised, django 1.9 or later issue this SQL:
```sql
SELECT "testapp_testparentmodel"."id", "testapp_testparentmodel"."age", COUNT("testapp_testchildmodel"."id") AS "cnt" FROM "testapp_testparentmodel" LEFT OUTER JOIN "testapp_testchildmodel" ON ("testapp_testparentmodel"."id" = "testapp_testchildmodel"."parent_id") GROUP BY "testapp_testparentmodel"."id"
```

items.title: Cannot create a second table

The milestone which had previously been called 0.8 has been renamed to 0.9.
https://github.com/shimizukawa/django-redshift-backend/milestone/1

items.body:
I have been using redshift with this package successfully with one model, but as I tried to create a second model on the redshift database, the migration step fails with

`django.db.utils.NotSupportedError: ALTER/CREATE TABLE column CHECK constraint is not supported`

The model is almost identical to the other one I have been using. I don't understand what `column CHECK constraint` is but everything looks ok. If I move this table to my second database, which is a vanilla Postgress, everything works fine.

Any ideas? Can I really only store one table per rredshift?

Complete stack:

```

  File "/opt/python/run/venv/local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/db/backends/utils.py", line 63, in execute

  File "/opt/python/run/venv/local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 363, in execute_from_command_line

  File "/opt/python/run/venv/local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 355, in execute

  File "/opt/python/run/venv/local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/commands/migrate.py", line 204, in handle
  fake_initial=fake_initial,
  File "/opt/python/run/venv/local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/db/migrations/executor.py", line 115, in migrate

  File "/opt/python/run/venv/local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/db/migrations/operations/models.py", line 97, in database_forwards
  schema_editor.create_model(model)
  File "/opt/python/ondeck/app/apps/redshift_backend/base.py", line 184, in create_model

items.title: Error on migrate: 'DatabaseSchemaEditor' object has no attribute 'sql_create_table_unique'

    targets, plan, fake=fake, fake_initial=fake_initial
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/django/db/migrations/executor.py", line 97, in migrate
    state = self._migrate_all_forwards(plan, full_plan, fake=fake, fake_initial=fake_initial)

Has it happened to someone else?

Thank you fellows

items.title: Compatibility with Django 1.11
items.body:
When running Django 1.11, Python 3.5.3 and django-redshift-backend 0.6, this exception is thrown:

```
Unhandled exception in thread started by <function check_errors.<locals>.wrapper at 0x7f3f8ce6c840>
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/virtualenvs/dwtools/lib/python3.5/site-packages/django/db/utils.py", line 115, in load_backend
    return import_module('%s.base' % backend_name)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/importlib/__init__.py", line 126, in import_module
    return _bootstrap._gcd_import(name[level:], package, level)
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 986, in _gcd_import
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 969, in _find_and_load
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 958, in _find_and_load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 673, in _load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap_external>", line 673, in exec_module
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 222, in _call_with_frames_removed
  File "/virtualenvs/dwtools/lib/python3.5/site-packages/django_redshift_backend/base.py", line 14, in <module>
    from django.db.backends.postgresql_psycopg2.base import (
ImportError: cannot import name 'BaseDatabaseValidation'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/virtualenvs/dwtools/lib/python3.5/site-packages/django/utils/autoreload.py", line 227, in wrapper
    fn(*args, **kwargs)

    return checks.run_checks(**kwargs)

    new_errors = check(app_configs=app_configs)

    errors.extend(field.check(**kwargs))

Here is the import that causes the exception: https://github.com/shimizukawa/django-redshift-backend/blob/eb91b6452721160bdc8d9c4be76916f66a4788a7/django_redshift_backend/base.py#L22

The identical setup works with Django 1.10.5.

items.title: SET TIMEZONE support

milestone.title: release-0.8
milestone.description:
Release (NEW) version 0.8 with current contents before making major changes.

The milestone which had previously been called 0.8 has been renamed to 0.9.
https://github.com/shimizukawa/django-redshift-backend/milestone/1

items.body:
django-redshift-backend 0.5 disables SET TIMEZONE because old version of Redshift didn't support it. 

Now Redshift supports timezone since version 1.0.1103 (2016-09-30).
https://aws.amazon.com/jp/about-aws/whats-new/2016/09/amazon-redshift-introduces-new-data-type-to-support-time-zones-in-time-stamps/

Note that, It's dependent on the environment whether timezone feature can be used. Therefore we should consider there are environments which can't be used the feature.

refs:
- timestamptz explanation in Japanese: http://dev.classmethod.jp/cloud/aws/amazon-redshift-new-data-type-timestamptz/

items.title: Django1.7 error on DatabaseWrapper ( no attribute "data_types" )
items.body:
This is my stack trace,

```
>>> TXCache.objects.using('redshift').count()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/ignaciodelamadrid/Development/venturefund.io/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/db/models/query.py", line 338, in count
    return self.query.get_count(using=self.db)
  File "/Users/ignaciodelamadrid/Development/venturefund.io/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/db/models/sql/query.py", line 436, in get_count
    number = obj.get_aggregation(using=using)[None]
  File "/Users/ignaciodelamadrid/Development/venturefund.io/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/db/models/sql/query.py", line 402, in get_aggregation
    result = query.get_compiler(using).execute_sql(SINGLE)
  File "/Users/ignaciodelamadrid/Development/venturefund.io/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/db/models/sql/query.py", line 224, in get_compiler
    connection = connections[using]
  File "/Users/ignaciodelamadrid/Development/venturefund.io/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/db/utils.py", line 242, in __getitem__
    backend = load_backend(db['ENGINE'])
  File "/Users/ignaciodelamadrid/Development/venturefund.io/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/db/utils.py", line 108, in load_backend
    return import_module('%s.base' % backend_name)
  File "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/importlib/__init__.py", line 37, in import_module
    __import__(name)
  File "/Users/ignaciodelamadrid/Development/venturefund.io/venturefund/db/backends/django-redshift/base.py", line 402, in <module>
    class DatabaseWrapper(BasePGDatabaseWrapper):
  File "/Users/ignaciodelamadrid/Development/venturefund.io/venturefund/db/backends/django-redshift/base.py", line 406, in DatabaseWrapper
    data_types = deepcopy(BasePGDatabaseWrapper.data_types)
AttributeError: type object 'DatabaseWrapper' has no attribute 'data_types'
```

I saw Django's repo and it seems that the 1.7 version doesn't declare the data_types dictionary in the DatabaseWrapper class in the django.db.backends.postgresql_psycopg2 module. Any hint on this? Are you guys going to support 1.7? upgrading is kind of difficult for me.
